translated: He should not look down on anyone, but should look upon all beings, good or bad, high or low, as if they were his only son.

original: glegs bam bklags par gsungs ba mi bya ba dang / dkyil 'khor dang / me tog bsdu bar mi bya ba dang / sngags kyi bzlas pa mi bya ba dang / lha dang dbang bskur ba la sogs pa la phyag mi bya ba dang / brdzun du smra ba dang /

translated: He should not read books, nor should he gather in a mandala, nor should he recite mantras, nor should he prostrate to deities or to those who have received empowerment, nor should he tell lies, nor should he be angry, nor should he be proud, nor should he be jealous, nor should he be stingy, nor should he be deceitful, nor should he be greedy, nor should he be attached to his body, nor should he be attached to his possessions, nor should he be attached to his life.

original: pha rol gyi bud med skal ba bzang mo bsten par bya ba dang / gdug pa can la byams pa mi bya bar gsungs pa dang / sangs rgyas dang / srog chags bsad pa dang / rgyal bas mchod pa'i slob dpon dang / ye shes kyi dam tshig sems can te dam tshig rtag tu dngos grub sna tshogs sbyin par byed de /

translated: The master who is worshipped by the Victorious Ones, and the sentient beings who are the pledge of pristine consciousness, always grant various spiritual powers to the one who has the pledges.

analyzed: ta ka ra'i mig sman gyis mi mthong bar 'gyur ro //
translated: With the eye ointment of the takra, one will not be seen.

original: ri bong can gyi chu dang / dza lu ka dang / sbal pa'i mar khu dang / p'a ta li'i rtsabs rkang pa'i mthil byugs na skyes bu me ma mur gyi tshogs la 'gro bar 'gyur ro //
analyzed: ri bong can gyi chu dang / dza lu ka dang / sbal pa'i mar khu dang / p'a ta li'i rtsabs rkang pa'i mthil byugs na skyes bu me ma mur gyi tshogs la 'gro bar 'gyur ro //
translated: With the water of the rabbit, the jaluka, the marrow of the frog, and the root of the patali, one should anoint the soles of the feet. The person will go to a heap of burning coals.

original: shra ma ni ka dang / sbal pa'i tshil bu dang / dza lo'u ka dang / zla ba las byung ba dang ldan pas lag pa dang / rkang pa byugs na me kha ba ltar bsil bar byed par 'gyur ro //
analyzed: shra ma ni ka dang / sbal pa'i tshil bu dang / dza lo'u ka dang / zla ba las byung ba dang ldan pas lag pa dang / rkang pa byugs na me kha ba ltar bsil bar byed par 'gyur ro //
translated: With the shramanika, the fat of the frog, the jaluka, and that which arises from the moon, one should anoint the hands and feet. The fire will become cool like snow.

original: kha'i nang du dun du ba'i rin po che bcug ste chur zhugs na sh'akya'i gnas kyi nang du zhugs pa lta bur blo dang ldan pa 'dod pas gnas so //
analyzed: kha'i nang du dun du ba'i rin po che bcug ste chur zhugs na sh'akya'i gnas kyi nang du zhugs pa lta bur blo dang ldan pa 'dod pas gnas so //
translated: Having placed the jewel of the dung beetle in the mouth and entered the water, the wise one will dwell as desired, like entering the abode of the Shakyas.

original: so na ga'i sa bon gyis rkang  ba'i lham zung byas na chu'i steng du skyes pa shin tu rnam par @425b dag pa gru lta bur 'chag cing 'gro bar 'gyur ro //
analyzed: so na ga'i sa bon gyis rkang  ba'i lham zung byas na chu'i steng du skyes pa shin tu rnam par @425b dag pa gru lta bur 'chag cing 'gro bar 'gyur ro //
translated: If one smears the soles of one‚Äôs feet with the seeds of the Indian sesbania, one will walk on water as if on dry land, like a boat.

original: mar sar dang / btsag skya bo dang / dri nga dang / nya'i mar khu'i tshigs mas bug pa thams cad byugs na skyes pa blo dang ldan pa chu srin lta bur rgyu bar 'gyur ro //
analyzed: mar sar dang / btsag skya bo dang / dri nga dang / nya'i mar khu'i tshigs mas bug pa thams cad byugs na skyes pa blo dang ldan pa chu srin lta bur rgyu bar 'gyur ro //
translated: If one smears all the orifices with ghee, white chalk, feces, and fish oil, one will become a wise man who moves like a crocodile.

original: sa bon dang / ka na ka'i drungs pa chen po'i srin bu'i phye ma dang ldan pa dang / kookki la rnams kyis skyes pa 'dror byed par 'gyur ro //
analyzed: sa bon dang / ka na ka'i drungs pa chen po'i srin bu'i phye ma dang ldan pa dang / kookki la rnams kyis skyes pa 'dror byed par 'gyur ro //
translated: One will be able to make a man impotent by using the seeds of the Indian sesbania, the powder of the great root of the kanaka plant, and the kokila bird.

original: bu ram dang / aa ra na la dag gis ni phyir bzlog par byed do //
analyzed: bu ram dang / aa ra na la dag gis ni phyir bzlog par byed do //
translated: One will be able to reverse the effect by using molasses and arana.

original: skye ba gnyis pa dang / byi la dang / spre'u dang / rang 'tsheng dang / khva'i dgra dang / sre mong gi spu rnams brdungs shing rtsa ra ma'i rtug pa'i phye mas 'jig rten pa thams cad smyo bar byed do //
analyzed: skye ba gnyis pa dang / byi la dang / spre'u dang / rang 'tsheng dang / khva'i dgra dang / sre mong gi spu rnams brdungs shing rtsa ra ma'i rtug pa'i phye mas 'jig rten pa thams cad smyo bar byed do //
translated: The second birth, cat, monkey, self-infatuation, mosquito, and mongoose fur are ground up with the powder of goat dung. This will drive all worldly beings mad.

original: ba glang tsha'i rnga ma dang / ka gnyis pa gshog pa g-yas pa dang ldan pa mal du bcug na myur du dgra bo brjed byed kyis 'jigs par byed do //
analyzed: ba glang tsha'i rnga ma dang / ka gnyis pa gshog pa g-yas pa dang ldan pa mal du bcug na myur du dgra bo brjed byed kyis 'jigs par byed do //
translated: If one places in one's bed the tail of a blue ox and a kanaka bird with its right wing, one will quickly be afflicted by the dread disease of insanity.

original: ka na ka'i 'bras bu dang // ma du lung ga dang / phug ron dang / rma bya dang / zangs kyi gtsug phud can gyis lan gcig smyo bar byed cing blo gros dang bral bar byed do //
analyzed: ka na ka'i 'bras bu dang // ma du lung ga dang / phug ron dang / rma bya dang / zangs kyi gtsug phud can gyis lan gcig smyo bar byed cing blo gros dang bral bar byed do //
translated: The fruit of the kanaka tree, madanaphala, pigeon, peacock, and copper-crested (bird) cause madness and loss of intelligence.

original: skra'i las kyi mtha' yin no //
analyzed: skra'i las kyi mtha' yin no //
translated: This concludes the rites of hair.

original: ka na ka'i 'bras bu blangs nas dam tshig chen po dang / srin bu'i phye ma dang bsres nas bza' ba dang btung ba la sbyar na de'i skad cig la smyo bar 'gyur te /
analyzed: ka na ka'i 'bras bu blangs nas dam tshig chen po dang / srin bu'i phye ma dang bsres nas bza' ba dang btung ba la sbyar na de'i skad cig la smyo bar 'gyur te /
translated: Take the fruit of the kanaka tree, mix it with the powder of great samaya worms, and add it to food and drink. In that very moment, one will go mad.

original: nyi ma bdun gyis 'chi bar 'gyur ro //
analyzed: nyi ma bdun gyis 'chi bar 'gyur ro //
translated: One will die within seven days.

original: tsha ba'i mar khus pi tsu ma rda'i shing la gtor zan gyi blangs te byugs nas lag pa de nyid kyis ma reg par du @426a *//
analyzed: tsha ba'i mar khus pi tsu ma rda'i shing la gtor zan gyi blangs te byugs nas lag pa de nyid kyis ma reg par du @426a *//

analyzed: khrod du shing bsregs pa'i thal ba blangs nas gang gi spyi bor byin pa de skrod par byed do //
translated: One should take the ashes of a burnt tree from a charnel ground, and give it to the head of the one whom one wants to expel.

original: rnam par shes pa dang / ye shes so //
analyzed: rnam par shes pa dang / ye shes so //
